commit.message: Update metadata for 0.5.16 release

Build: Remove getopt from libmissing

FreeBSD 14.0 and 13.3 generate the following compilation warning:
>
> In file included from munge/src/munge/munge.c:58:
> munge/src/libmissing/getopt.h:147:12: warning: a function declaration
>   without a prototype is deprecated in all versions of C and is treated
>   as a zero-parameter prototype in C2x, conflicting with a previous
>   declaration [-Wdeprecated-non-prototype]
> extern int getopt ();
>            ^
> /usr/include/unistd.h:378:6: note: conflicting prototype is here
> int      getopt(int, char * const [], const char *);
>          ^
> 1 warning generated.

In commit 80dd834, GNU getopt from glibc-2.3.2 was imported into
libmissing in order to use long options on systems that did not
include getopt_long().  This old version of getopt is now producing
compilation warnings on recent FreeBSD releases.

The first BSD implementation of getopt_long() appeared in NetBSD 1.5.
FreeBSD first included it in FreeBSD 5.0.  And the implementation
first appeared in OpenBSD 3.3.

Since recent systems include getopt_long(), getopt can safely be
removed from libmissing.

>     in use at exit: 5,341 bytes in 13 blocks
>   total heap usage: 7,706 allocs, 7,693 frees, 1,505,332 bytes allocated

> 32 bytes in 1 blocks are still reachable in loss record 5 of 13

these errors.

maintained by the version control system.

Sharness: Set SHARNESS_TEST_OUTDIR to CWD for VPATH

If SHARNESS_TEST_OUTDIR is not defined, VPATH builds can clobber the
SHARNESS_TRASH_DIRECTORY making it difficult to diagnose failures in
the test suite.

The SHARNESS_TRASH_DIRECTORY is the HOME directory for a given
sharness test script, and it is recreated at the start of the script's
execution.  If the "root" variable is defined, it is prepended
to this directory pathname.  Then, if the trash directory is a
relative pathname (as it is in the default case), it is prepended
with SHARNESS_TEST_OUTDIR.  If SHARNESS_TEST_OUTDIR is not defined,
it defaults to SHARNESS_TEST_DIRECTORY, the directory containing the
sharness test script in the source tree.  This results in VPATH builds
clobbering the same trash directory for a given test script.

Prevent VPATH builds from clobbering the trash directory by setting
the current working directory as the default SHARNESS_TEST_OUTDIR.
This relocates the default trash directory from the source tree to
the build tree.

libmunge: Fix connect failure retry for full socket queue

libmunge retries transient errors when connecting to munged.
This should handle errors arising from the listening socket's queue
being full.  However, PR #139 uncovered a bug that did not handle
EAGAIN which is returned on Linux when a nonblocking UNIX domain
socket connection cannot be completed immediately.

This commit fixes the while-loop in _m_msg_client_connect() that
retries connect() so both EAGAIN (Linux) and ECONNREFUSED (BSD)
are handled as transient errors that should be retried.

This was tested by setting "--listen-backlog=1", running munged
with the default 2 work threads, and running remunge with 64
threads.  First, the while-loop was altered so connect() errors
would not be retried.  remunge could reproduce EAGAIN on Linux,
and this behavior was dramatically more reproducible if vcpu > 1.
remunge could reproduce ECONNREFUSED on NetBSD 9.3 with vcpu=1, and
on FreeBSD 14.0 with vcpu=2.  Adding back the retry logic for EAGAIN
and ECONNREFUSED made this connect() failure difficult to reproduce
even with "--listen-backlog=1".

commit.message:
munged: Allow listen-backlog to specify default or SOMAXCONN

Change the behavior of the "--listen-backlog" command-line
option in order for a value of 0 to use the software default
(MUNGE_SOCKET_BACKLOG), and a value of -1 to specify SOMAXCONN.

Note that SOMAXCONN is now 4096 on current Linux systems; it was 128
before Linux 5.4 which meant that the munged socket had been using
the maximum backlog up until that point.

Reference:
- https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/networking/ip-sysctl.html

PR #139

munged: Add --listen-backlog option

Add the "--listen-backlog" command-line option to specify the socket's
listen backlog limit.

On a very busy cluster, slurmctld failed to connect to munged to decode
a credential.  The returned error message was "Resource temporarily
unavailable" (EAGAIN).  Increasing the munged listen backlog prevented
this error from reoccurring.

PR #139
Signed-off-by: Chris Dunlap <cdunlap@llnl.gov>

Sharness: Remove munge user in 1000-chaos-rpm.t

The "munge" user and group are created in the %pre section of the
specfile which is run when the munge RPM is installed.

Remove the munge user (which will also remove its group) at the end
of the test in order to ensure the user and group will be recreated
when the RPM is installed.

Build: Remove backward compatibility for AC_PROG_LIBTOOL

In commit f9485ad (2005), AC_PROG_LIBTOOL was replaced with LT_INIT
(the new setup macro added to libtool 2).  Then in commit b86188a
(2018), backward compatibility support was added via m4_ifdef to
use AC_PROG_LIBTOOL if the LT_INIT macro was undefined; this allowed
"./bootstrap" to run on old test systems such as Debian 5.0.10 and 4.0.

However, commit b86188a specifies a prereq for autoconf-2.61 (2006)
and commit c32ba0c specifies a prereq for automake-1.12 (2012).
Since LT_INIT has been available in libtool since at least 2005,
it seems safe to remove backward compatibility for AC_PROG_LIBTOOL.

Note that a prereq is not currently specified for libtool.  While the
LT_PREREQ(version) macro exists, testing in commit b86188a showed
incorrect results when used with old versions of libtool.

Build: Remove backward compatibility for no AM_SILENT_RULES

Remove the m4_ifdef conditional enabling backward compatibility for
versions of automake that do not include the AM_SILENT_RULES macro.

In commit 0e107fa, the AM_SILENT_RULES macro call was added with an
m4_ifdef conditional to enable backward compatibility for running
"./bootstrap" with automake-1.10 (since AM_SILENT_RULES was introduced
in automake-1.11).  However, commit c32ba0c now requires automake-1.12
or later which means this m4_ifdef is no longer relevant.

Note that as of automake-1.13, specifying the AM_SILENT_RULES macro
or silent-rules option is no longer necessary since all generated
Makefiles will support silent rules, either by running "./configure
--enable-silent-rules" or "make V=0"; however, verbose ("V=1") builds
will be enabled by default unless the AM_SILENT_RULES macro is called
with a "yes" value.

Reference:
- https://autotools.info/automake/silent.html

libmunge: Fix err msg suggestion for client ENOENT

In libmunge, _m_msg_client_connect() stat()s the munged listening
socket before attempting connect().  An error is returned to the
client if the stat() fails.  In commit f56acfe, this error message was
changed for the case of ENOENT to add a suggestion to start munged.
However, that change was not limited to just ENOENT.  Consequently,
EACCES (permission denied) now returns this suggestion to start munged
which is wrong.

Fix the error message to only suggest starting munged for the case
of ENOENT.

Sharness: Reorder rpm -qa check in 1000-chaos-rpm.t

Reorder the "rpm --query --all" check so that it occurs after the
SUDO sharness prereq since the rpm query could take several seconds
(thereby making it more "expensive" in time).  This allows the test
to more quickly skip if TEST_LONG is not set.
